claim_target: Kanger Valley National Park is a national park located in the Indian state of Chhattisgarh, in the Kanger Ghati valley. It is home to three exceptional caves – known for their amazing geological structures of Kutumbasar, Kailash and Dandak- Stellagmites and Stalactitees . National Park is known for the presence of underground limestone caves with dripstone and floston. The stalegmites and stalactite formation is still increasing. query: India: Which type of surface formations and caves can be found in Kanger Valley National Park?

The vast undulating terrain of the Kanger Valley National Park harbors diverse habitats which offer an ideal site for diverse kinds of flora and fauna, thus making it a hotspot of biodiversity in Central India. Kanger Valley National Park has been situated 24 km, Southeast of Jagdalpur, the headquarters of Bastar district, on Jagdalpur -Darbha Road. The National Park derives its name from the Kanger River, which flows centrally from the Northwest to the Southeast direction.

Tirathgarh Waterfall is located in Kanger Valley National Park.

claim_target: Borra Caves are essentially a natural limestone cave in India. The cave is located in the Ananthagiri Hills of the Eastern Ghats, near Araku Valley in Andhra Pradesh. This pre-historic cave has been explored and excavated by archaeologists and speleologists, who have discovered important artifacts and evidence of human habitation. It is the origin of the Gosthani River that flows from here to Visakhapatnam . Unfortunately, Borra Caves are not as well maintained in India as in other countries. Due to human touch, the natural growth stops. There is no restriction or even instructions for not touching. The nearest international airport is Visakhapatnam Airport, 76 km (47 mi) from Borra Caves, which is 12 kilometres (7.5 mi) from the Visakhapatnam city center.
query: India: Who has explored and excavated Borra Caves, discovering artifacts and evidence of human habitation?
evidence: These caves were discovered by William King George of the Geological Survey of India. Legend has it that Borra Caves was first discovered when a cowherd, while searching for one of his lost cows, accidentally came across them. There he found a shivling deep inside the cave, along with his cow. He believed that Lord Shiva had saved his cow.

claim_target: The waterlogged church situated in the backwaters of the Gorur Dam in Karnataka was constructed in 1860 by a French missionary named Abbe J A Dubois from ordinary bricks, mortar, glass from Belgium, Egyptian gypsum, jaggery, and eggshells. The church is a masterpiece in many ways and has become a popular tourist spot, attracting a large number of tourists. It still stands with only about one-third of its structure above the water’s surface during peak monsoon from June to October. Over the years, it has acquired names like ‘Floating Church’ and ‘Submerged Church’.
query: Karnataka: Where is the Shettihalli Rosary Church submerged, making it a popular tourist attraction in Karnataka?
evidence: During the monsoons, if you visit Shettihalli in Karnataka’s Hassan district, about 200km from Bengaluru, you will find a church floating in the backwaters of the Hemavati River. The 212-year-old Shettihalli Rosary Church has been submerging in water between July and October annually since 1960. Only the top one-third of the structure is visible during the monsoons. Also known as the floating or submerged church, it was abandoned in 1960 after the construction of Hemavati Dam and Reservoir which redirected the waters of the river and submerged 28 villages in the vicinity.
edited_claim: The waterlogged church situated in the backwaters of the Gorur Dam in Karnataka was constructed in 1803 by a French missionary named Abbe J A Dubois from stones, bricks, mortar, glass from Belgium, jaggery, and eggshells. The church is a masterpiece in many ways and has become a popular tourist spot, attracting a large number of tourists. It still stands with only about one-third of its structure above the water’s surface during peak monsoon from June to October. Over the years, it has acquired names like ‘Floating Church’ and ‘Submerged Church’.

claim_target: Jogimara Cave is a natural cave in Surguja, India. It is one of the most prominent landmarks in the region, located on the southern slopes of Amrit Dhara waterfall - a 10.0-15.0 ft (3.0-4.6 metres) deep pothole with the stream Kharun Nala flowing into it.
query: Surguja: Which waterfall is situated near the Jogimara Cave in Surguja?
evidence: The Jogimara and Sitabenga caves are in Surguja district of Chhattisgarh, about 45 kilometers southwest of Ambikapur , 180 kilometers northeast of Bilaspur city, and 5 kilometers from Khodri. It is connected by India's national highway 130, then a small spur road that climbs up into the Ramgarh hills (also called the Ramgiri hills or Devapahari), giving this site the alternate name of Ramgarh caves . Midst the two forested hills, the spur road reaches Ram Janaki temple and nearby Hindu temple ruins. Thereafter, the caves are a short hike west on a marked, stone paved trail with a seasonal waterfall and a natural lake.
edited_claim: Jogimara Cave is a natural cave in Surguja, India. It is one of the most prominent landmarks in the region, located on a spur road that climbs up into the Ramgarh hills (also called the Ramgiri hills or Devapahari). The caves are a short hike west from Hindu temple ruins.

claim_target: The Gandhara, Kruru or Pana was a unit of currency used in ancient India. Its name comes from Sanskrit words 'gaṇa' and 'dāra', which mean "treasure" and "holder" respectively, referring to the coins that were used as a medium of exchange.

[1] and the British Raj in the 19th century. [4] Origin of currency in Indian subcontinent [ edit ]
edited_claim: The Gandhara was a unit of currency used in ancient India. Its name comes from the Sanskrit word 'gaṇa' which means "treasure" referring to the coins that were used as a medium of exchange.

The strains of the sitar, the tabla, and the shehnai reverberate through the narrow lanes, enchanting listeners and invoking a sense of transcendence. The city has been a patron of renowned musicians and dancers, and its ghats often serve as natural amphitheaters for impromptu performances, particularly during festivals such as Dev Deepawali and Mahashivratri.

claim_target: Traditional Bhangra is a name or prefix used for several rhythmic variants, such as traditional bhangra and modern bhangra. These forms are significant aspects of Punjabi culture, often recognized as Bhangra. The dance form symbolizes the imagination, potential, talent, and charisma of the people performing it. It is associated primarily with the spring harvest festival Baisakhi, and it is from one of the major products of the harvest— bhang (hemp)—that bhangra drew its name. In a typical performance, several dancers executed vigorous kicks, leaps, and bends of the body to the accompaniment of short songs called boliyan and, most significantly, to the beat of a dhol (double-headed drum). With the change in context came changes in other aspects of tradition. There are many Bhangra competitions held all over India, especially in Punjab for several decades. This dance form is developed by a dance troupe led by brothers from the Deepak family of Sunam, Punjab (Manohar, Avtar and Gurbachan)
query: Punjab: Which region is the origin of various forms of folk dance known as Bhangra?
evidence: Punjab portal v t e Punjabi dances are an array of folk and religious dances of the Punjabi people indigenous to the Punjab region, straddling the border of India and Pakistan. The style of Punjabi dances ranges from very high energy to slow and reserved, and there are specific styles for men and women. Types [ edit ] Bhangra [ edit ] Bhangra dancers in Punjab, India Bhangra is the most popular folk dance from Punjab, originating in the Sialkot area of Punjab , Pakistan .
edited_claim: Bhangra is a name of a traditional folk dance of Punjab, originating in the Sialkot area of Punjab, Pakistan. It is associated primarily with the spring harvest festival Baisakhi, and it is from one of the major products of the harvest— bhang (hemp)—that bhangra drew its name. In a typical performance, several dancers executed vigorous kicks, leaps, and bends of the body to the accompaniment of short songs called boliyan and, most significantly, to the beat of a dhol (double-headed drum). With the change in context came changes in other aspects of tradition. There are many Bhangra competitions held all over India, especially in Punjab for several decades. This dance form is developed by a dance troupe led by brothers from the Deepak family of Sunam, Punjab (Manohar, Avtar and Gurbachan)

edited_claim: Kaaja is a popular meringue-based dessert in Andhra Pradesh, said to have been developed by a group of weavers who were looking for a way to use up leftover rice flour. The name Kaaja comes from the city of Kakinada. It is one of the most popular Andhra sweets and has a rich history and tradition.

claim_target: Double-ka-meetha is a dessert from North India traditionally prepared during the Eid festival in Hyderabad. The festival primarily celebrates the end of Ramadan. Double-ka-meetha is considered a celebratory sweet. It is known as Mauz ka MItha or banana sweet in Hyderabadi language.
query: Hyderabad: Which festival is double-ka-meetha commonly associated with in Hyderabad?
evidence: Double kaa Meetha is a famous Mughlai dessert from the state of Hyderabad. A Sahi dessert where Double Roti aka Bread is fried in Pure Ghee and then soaked in Sugar Syrup. This is then again soaked in Rabri and flavored with Rosewater and dry fruits. It is said that this dessert is loved by the Royal family of Hyderabad a lot.
edited_claim: Double-ka-meetha is a dessert from North India traditionally prepared for celebrations. It is made with bread fried in pure ghee and soaked in sugar syrup and rabri, flavored with rosewater and dry fruits. The royal family of Hyderabad loves it.
